hobby.message: Still flying like no one's watching?
I hear analog photography still survives in your hands.
Origami helping you dodge the spiral?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Quiet, yes. The city feels...different lately.
I fold origami, just paper, nothing unusual.
Mostly old forms. Ordinary patterns, not much else.
Supplies are harder to find after the recent events.
It’s not just tonight—streets have emptied since the protests.
I do origami sometimes. Paper shapes.
Was hard to find decent paper this week. Notices everywhere.
Kept to smaller folds to avoid wasting anything.
Too much attention on scrap collectors lately.
Quieter than usual. The tension’s almost thicker than the crowds lately.
Origami helps me stay focused. I fold whatever scraps I can find.
Lost most of my favorite patterns—had to improvise with official flyers.
Since the leaks, everyone’s watching what you carry, even paper.
I keep it simple, mostly cranes and cubes now.
It’s odd—turning warnings into art calms me.
It’s almost silent out there, except for crowds near the big screens.
Honestly, I fold origami every night to clear my head.
Lately, I’m using protest leaflets and service notices—plenty to choose from lately.
Some patterns are tricky, but repetition’s comforting. Cranes, cubes, even modular stars if I have enough paper.
Lost an old diagram book in a sweep, had to memorize the hard ones.
Last weekend, I ended up teaching a neighbor. Weirdly grounding.
Makes the noise outside feel...less intrusive, even now.
Quieter than it should be, which makes the tension worse somehow.
I started folding origami after Halden introduced it at a team retreat—said it helped with the stress loops.
Now it’s habit. After the billboard leaks, I collected protest flyers to keep myself busy.
Had to get creative—folded Council notices into interlocking stars, cranes from disappearances lists.
Sometimes I hide tiny folds in the stairwell—just to prove I made something else out of surveillance.
Lost my best paper stash last month after my BCI dropped. Can't risk carrying much now.
Last night, a neighbor joined me. Used to fold alone, but sharing the process makes everything outside seem far away.
Strange, but turning official warnings into something delicate—almost feels like reclaiming a little control.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still folding.
Shreds of protest flyers everywhere now. Makes for... interesting paper.
Doesn’t draw attention unless you leave a mess.
Quiet hobby. No one asks questions.
Best to keep to myself lately.
I do, yes. Keeps my hands busy.
Found lots of Council bulletins in the stairwells lately.
Origami shapes distract from all the shouting and crowd noise.
The power flickers make it tricky to see clean edges.
I don’t use colored paper anymore. Too noticeable.
Safer to stick with whatever’s left lying around.
I still fold—inasmuch as I can find good paper.
Most times it’s old memos now or discarded notices from the protests.
Last week I shaped a cube from a BCI printout. Strange satisfaction.
Feels like folding order into all the public chaos for a second.
My neighbor joined in when the outage hit—quiet company, less tension.
It helps, even if my BCI keeps dropping.
At least small, bright things come out of it.
Definitely. It’s something that never flags me... yet.
After Lenart’s leaks, the city’s full of flyers and scraps. Good for cranes.
Sometimes I fold the official warnings—transform them into something different.
Had to teach myself modular origami during the blackout. More complex, distracting.
Made a whole flock while alarms were echoing outside.
Other residents saw me—some wanted to learn, just for a break.
Funny how shared folding muted the fear for a while.
Now my BCI’s low, I fold quietly, but it still gives calm.
Origami’s still my reset button—has been since way before the BCI.
I used to fold official memos before shredding; now it’s leaked score sheets.
The night Lenart exposed the Council’s scoring, I sat in the dark folding cubes.
Every click of the mains, protests and sirens got louder. My hands just kept folding.
Neighbors left protest printouts by my door—almost like an offering.
I taught a few people how to make modular stars during the last blackout.
Feels odd, making beauty from things meant to scare us.
Folding together made conversation easier—we whispered things the system would never log.
Honestly, this hobby’s the only routine that survived everything the city broke.
